title: 108_hr3720
content: The Act titled "Empowering Parents and Teachers for a Drug-Free Education Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. The Congress finds that a significant percentage of high school students in 2001 had used illicit drugs and alcohol, with a notable increase in MDMA use among 12th graders. This substance abuse poses risks to student health, safety, and the learning environment. Illicit drugs and alcohol pose health risks, impact learning environment by affecting brain function, causing disruptive behavior, lowering academic performance, and increasing rule-breaking among students. SEC. 3. DRUG-FREE SCHOOL DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS. Amends the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act to include Drug-Free School Demonstration Programs. The Secretary may provide grants to local educational agencies and private schools for drug-free school demonstration programs. These programs must include random drug testing of students, the use of FDA-approved drug tests, analysis by certified laboratories, review by a medical officer, and no disclosure of results to law enforcement. The random drug testing program for students includes review by a medical officer, strict confidentiality of records, destruction of records for unconfirmed results, and parental notification and opt-out rights. The random drug-testing program for students includes informing parents, allowing them to opt-out, setting clear behavior policies, providing drug and alcohol abuse prevention training, and offering student assistance. The drug-free school program includes drug and alcohol abuse prevention training, student access to assistance programs, and continuing education. Privacy protection measures ensure confidentiality of student drug test results and prohibit mandatory disclosure of medical information unless a student tests positive for drugs. The program includes drug and alcohol abuse prevention training, student access to assistance programs, and continuing education. It prohibits mandatory disclosure of medical information unless a student tests positive for drugs and requires a medical review officer to report test results confidentially in writing. Technical assistance may be provided through contracts with public and private entities. Applications for grants must be submitted to the Secretary following specific requirements. The section defines a medical review officer as a licensed physician knowledgeable about substance abuse disorders, excluding school employees or those with a financial interest in the laboratory. It also defines a student as an individual enrolled in grades 8 through 12. The Secretary of Education must report on drug-free school programs within 18 months. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. Congress requires a report on drug-free school demonstration programs funded under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Authorization of $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2005 and subsequent years is allocated for these programs. Amendments are made to the table of contents to reflect these changes.
